FLECS: A Federated Learning Second-Order Framework via Compression and Sketching

Artem Agafonov Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE Dmitry Kamzolov Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Rachael Tappenden University of Canterbury, Christchurch 8041, New Zealand Alexander Gasnikov Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Institute for Information Transmission Problems, Moscow, Russia HSE University, Moscow, Russia Martin TakÃ¡Ä Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE
Abstract

Inspired by the recent work FedNL (Safaryan et al, FedNL: Making Newton-Type Methods Applicable to Federated Learning), we propose a new communication efficient second-order framework for Federated learning, namely FLECS. The proposed method reduces the high-memory requirements of FedNL by the usage of an L-SR1 type update for the Hessian approximation which is stored on the central server. A low dimensional â€˜sketchâ€™ of the Hessian is all that is needed by each device to generate an update, so that memory costs as well as number of Hessian-vector products for the agent are low. Biased and unbiased compressions are utilized to make communication costs also low. Convergence guarantees for FLECS are provided in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases, and local linear convergence is also established under strong convexity. Numerical experiments confirm the practical benefits of this new FLECS algorithm.

1 Introduction

This paper presents a novel second-order method for Federated Learning called FLECS. In this setup, multiple agents/devices/workers collaborate to solve a machine learning problem by communicating over a central node (server). It is assumed that the central node is a large and powerful machine, but the agents/devices are much smaller (for example, a cellphone, or laptop). Moreover, raw data is stored locally on each worker and cannot be exchanged or transferred. The finite sum minimization, or Federated Learning, problem can be formalized in the following way:

minwâˆˆâ„dâ¡{Fâ€‹(w):=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfiâ€‹(w)},subscriptğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘assignğ¹ğ‘¤1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤\textstyle{\min}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{F(w):=\tfrac{1}{n}\textstyle{\sum}_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(w)\right\}, (1)

where fiâ€‹(w)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¤f_{i}(w) is the loss function (parametrized by wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}) associated with the data stored on the iğ‘–i-th machine, Fâ€‹(w)ğ¹ğ‘¤F(w) is the empirical loss function, and both the problem dimension dğ‘‘d, and the number of machines nğ‘›n, can be large.
Problems of the form (1) arise not only in distributed machine learning [23, 24], but also in robotics, resource allocation, power system control, control of drone or satellite networks, distributed statistical inference and optimal transport, and multi-agent reinforcement learning [39, 33, 28, 14, 37, 35].
A variety of first-ordered methods have been introduced for the problem (1) under the stated computational set-up (a central server connected to multiple smaller devices). Early work includes that of [10, 11, 26], which focused on distributed first order optimization algorithms that were designed with the computational structure in mind. Recent advances include works focusing on reducing the communication burden via compression techniques [2, 19, 9], including momentum for algorithm speed up [27, 43], variance reduction techniques [20], the use of adaptive learning rates [40], and works that focus on maintaining client data privacy [16].
Beyond first-order methods, second-order methods have also been developed for Federated Learning. Some of these algorithms [42, 15, 12, 5, 1] utilize statistical similarity (the homogeneous data setting), which, roughly speaking, means that the local functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are similar, and they approximate the overall empirical risk function Fğ¹F well. FedNL [36] for the second-order method for Federated Learning in the case of heterogeneous data. While FedNL makes a valuable step toward the applicability of second-order methods to Federated Learning, this framework seems to be impractical for large-scaled problems, since dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d Hessian approximations are stored locally on workers and transferred to the server via compressed matrix communications. (This violates the assumption in the current work, that the individual workers have small memory.)
The goal here is to build upon the work in [36] and develop a new second order framework for Federated Learning that is based upon more realistic assumptions about the available computational architecture. That is, we assume that individual workers are devices with relatively low memory availability and computational capacity (e.g. mobile phones), but they can connect to a large and powerful central machine. The typical situation, that downloading is much faster than uploading, is also assumed. 111 An example of such a setting is (e.g., battery powered) wireless network [34, 41] where the cost of sending data from devices to the centralized server is energy demanding, implying severely limited communication bandwidth to the server [18, 8]. On the other hand, the server is usually connected to an energy network and has no constraints for sending data to other devices in the network. We introduce the FLECS second-order framework for strongly convex and non-convex optimization, which places no additional memory on workers and reduces the number Hessian-vector products per node. Therefore, our algorithm can be viewed as the lightweight FedNL, since it provides similar theoretical guarantees and has almost the same global. FLECS uses sketching [38] and matrix compression for efficient communication and allows for several Hessian learning techniques (including truncated LSR1 update) and two iterate updates, namely Truncated inverse Hessian approximation and FedSONIA, inspired by [30] and [22].

1.1 Contributions

We propose FLECS: a Federated LEarning Second-Order Framework via Compression and Sketching with the following properties.

  • â€¢

    No additional storage on workers. In large-scale machine learning problems, it is impossible to store the dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d-dimensional Hessian approximations. For a dataset with d=50,000ğ‘‘50000d=50,000 features, the local Hessian approximation requires more than 101010 GB of memory. For FLECS, the Hessian approximations are stored on the server, so memory requirements for the individual workers remain low.

  • â€¢

    Efficient communication via sketching and compression. To reduce the cost of communication, we use a sketching technique. This allows the exchange of dÃ—mğ‘‘ğ‘šd\times m matrices instead of dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d, where mâ‰ªdmuch-less-thanğ‘šğ‘‘m\ll d is the user defined memory size, which could be set as m=1ğ‘š1m=1. Moreover, we exploit compression to make the algorithm even more communication-efficient. This strategy heavily improves the one in [36], since we decrease the dimension of the transferred matrices d/mğ‘‘ğ‘šd/m times. Moreover, sketching reduces the number of Hessian-vector products from dğ‘‘d to mğ‘šm.

  • â€¢

    Heterogeneous data setting. Our framework is flexible and does not assume that data on the workers is independent and identically distributed.

  • â€¢

    Hessian Learning via Quasi-Newton updates. Motivated by quasi-Newton methods, sketching techniques and inverse Hessian truncation, we propose the Truncated L-SR1 update and Direct update for our Hessian approximations.

  • â€¢

    Theoretical Analysis. Convergence guarantees in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases, are provided, as well as a local linear rate of convergence under strong convexity independent of problem conditioning.

  • â€¢

    Competitive Numerical Experiments. Our numerical experiments highlight the practical benefits of our proposed framework.

Organization.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Related works are described in Section 2. Section 3 presents the proposed framework, including all algorithmic details. In SectionÂ 4, we establish theoretical convergence guarantees (all proofs can be found in the appendix). Numerical experiments are provided in Section 5 (additional experiments are provided in the appendix), and concluding remarks and potential future research directions are given in SectionÂ 6.

2 Related Work

Second-order methods are well established in the optimization literature. Such methods employ the Hessian (or an approximation to it) and thereby important (possibly approximate and/or partial) curvature information is available for utilization. The benefits include â€˜betterâ€™ search directions, and faster rates of convergence that may be independent of the condition number, although the algorithms often have higher memory and computational requirements than first order methods. To balance the trade off between improved convergence rates versus increased costs, approaches that involve modifying or approximating the Hessian have been proposed, and several of these are discussed now.
Arguably, some of the most popular algorithms that use approximations to the Hessian are quasi-Newton methods. They employ information from the iterates to build an approximation to the Hessian that improves in accuracy as the algorithm progresses. Among these are algorithms that use BFGS, SR1, and DFP updates [17, 29, 13], which are now considered to be classics in optimization due to their effectiveness and practicality, and also because, under certain conditions, theoretical results related to the accuracy of the Hessian approximations are available. This motivates the current work, which incorporates quasi-Newton type updates to learn a good approximation to the Hessian.
Of particular interest is the SR1 update, which does not guarantee positive definiteness of the Hessian approximation [13]. Previously, this was considered to be a disadvantage, but in the case of non-convex optimization, it would appear to be advantageous. L-SR1, a limited memory variant of SR1, belongs to the class of limited memory quasi-Newton algorithms [25, 4]. These methods store only the last mğ‘šm gradient differences Yk=[ykâˆ’m+1,â€¦,yk]subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘š1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜Y_{k}=[y_{k-m+1},\ldots,y_{k}] and iterate differences Sk=[skâˆ’m+1,â€¦,sk]subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘š1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜S_{k}=[s_{k-m+1},\ldots,s_{k}], where mğ‘šm is the memory size, yk=âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wk)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wkâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1y_{k}=\nabla F(w_{k})-\nabla F(w_{k-1}) and sk=wkâˆ’wkâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1s_{k}=w_{k}-w_{k-1}. The compact form of the L-SR1 update is [6]

Bk=B0+(Ykâˆ’B0â€‹Sk)â€‹Mkâˆ’1â€‹(Ykâˆ’B0â€‹Sk)T,subscriptğµğ‘˜subscriptğµ0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğµ0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğµ0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘‡B_{k}=B_{0}+(Y_{k}-B_{0}S_{k})M_{k}^{-1}(Y_{k}-B_{0}S_{k})^{T}, (2)

where Mk=Lk+Dk+LkTâˆ’SkTâ€‹B0â€‹Sksubscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğµ0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜M_{k}=L_{k}+D_{k}+L_{k}^{T}-S_{k}^{T}B_{0}S_{k}, SkTâ€‹Yk=Lk+Dk+Uksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘˜subscriptğ·ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜~{}S_{k}^{T}Y_{k}=L_{k}+D_{k}+U_{k}, Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} is diagonal, Lksubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜L_{k}, Uksubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜U_{k} are strictly lower and upper triangular, and B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is the initial approximation.
The work [3] proposed the use of a sampled Sksubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{k}, rather than one based upon the previous mğ‘šm iterate differences. The idea is, given the current iterate wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}, simply sample mğ‘šm random directions, and use the differences with wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} as the columns of sksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s_{k} (forming Yksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜Y_{k} appropriately). An Sksubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{k} with this form can be viewed as sketching matrix [38], and the Newton Sketch algorithm in [31], shows that even randomly projected or a sub-sampled Hessian provides enough curvature information for fast convergence.
The Nonconvex Newton method of [30] is a different approach, which is an adaptation of Newtonâ€™s method for nonconvex problems. At each iteration, the singular value decomposition of the Hessian is computed, small eigenvalues (in absolute value) are truncated, and then a positive definite modification of the Hessian is constructed. This is then used to create Newton-type direction.
SONIA [22] bridges the gap between first-order and second-order methods, combining the ideas of quasi-Newton algorithms, sketching [31] and truncation [30]. It constructs the search directions using curvature information in one subspace and gradient information in the orthogonal complement.
Second-order methods for Federated Learning, can generally be divided in two groups, based upon whether a homogeneous or heterogeneous data setting is assumed. Algorithms in the first group rely on the concept of statistical similarity, which, in practice, means that each local function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is a â€˜goodâ€™ approximation of the global objective function Fğ¹F. (More formally, â€–âˆ‡2Fâˆ’âˆ‡2fiâ€–â‰¤Î²normsuperscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ›½\|\nabla^{2}F-\nabla^{2}f_{i}\|\leq\beta for some Î²>0ğ›½0\beta>0.) Usually, in this case, methods utilize the part of the data stored on the server and use it to approximate the full Hessian [42, 15, 12, 5, 1].
No such statistical similarity (i.i.d.) assumption is made in the heterogeneous setting, which is perhaps more realistic (e.g., it may be impossible/impractical to have local data (on a mobile phone say), that approximates the data on the server well). The main work in this setting is FedNL [36]. The authors proposed a way to learn Hessian approximations and then take an approximate Newton-type step. However, the main drawback is that the Hessian approximations are stored locally and communications performed via compressed dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d matrices. For large-scale optimization problems, it is impossible to store the dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d matrix locally, because of memory limitations. Extensions of FedNL can be found in [21], [32].
The approach proposed here combines ideas from quasi-Newton methods, sketching, and Hessian learning, and develops a second-order Federated Learning framework with efficient communications and without an additional memory burden on workers. All Hessian approximations are stored on the server, not the workers. Communications are based on a user-defined memory hyperparameter mğ‘šm and utilize compression to reduce communication. Sketching allows to transfer dÃ—mğ‘‘ğ‘šd\times m matrices and reduce the number of Hessian-vector products on the worker. The proposed framework allows for two Hessian learning techniques and two iterate update rules. The Truncated Inverse Hessian approximation is based on the idea of truncating eigenvalues (as in [30]) of Hessian approximate, while FedSONIA is based upon SONIA [22] and reduces the iteration complexity of the step from Oâ€‹(d3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘3O(d^{3}) to Oâ€‹(nâ€‹mâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2O(nmd^{2}).

3 FLECS

Inspired by the works [22, 36], we propose a general framework for second-order methods for federated learning problems (1) that allows for different forms for the iterates and different Hessian approximations/updates. One of main goals of this framework is to create fast communication-efficient second-order methods that do not place additional memory requirements on the workers.
To make broadcasting between the server and nodes cheap we employ sketching and compression. Throughout the paper, Skâˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šS_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} denotes a sketching matrix, where mğ‘šm is the memory size (mâ‰ªdmuch-less-thanğ‘šğ‘‘m\ll d). Any operator that compresses a matrix is denoted by ğ’:â„dÃ—mâ†’â„dÃ—m:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} , e.g. random dithering, Rank-Rğ‘…R, Top-Kğ¾K, Rand-Kğ¾K (description of compressors can be found in Appendix C). The Hessian approximation of the iğ‘–i-th worker at iteration kğ‘˜k is denoted by Bkisuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘–B_{k}^{i}, and is stored on the central node.

The algorithm is initialized with a user defined memory size mâ‰ªdmuch-less-thanğ‘šğ‘‘m\ll d, and nğ‘›n matrices B0iâˆˆâ„dÃ—dsuperscriptsubscriptğµ0ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘B_{0}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} are stored on the central node, each representing an approximation to the local Hessian for the iğ‘–ith worker. At iteration k>0ğ‘˜0k>0 of FLECS, mğ‘šm directions {s1,â€¦,sm}subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘š\left\{s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}\right\} are randomly sampled at all nodes (including the server) and combined together, forming the columns of a sketching matrix Skâˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šS_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}. Definition 1 was proposed in [30] and was used to provide a convergence guarantee for their Nonconvex Newton method (to a local minimum). Firstly, an eigen-decomposition of Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} is computed, but with every eigenvalue replaced by its absolute value. Secondly, a thresholding step is applied, so that any eigenvalue (in absolute value) that is smaller (resp. greater) than a user defined threshold Ï‰ğœ”\omega (resp. Secondly, it ensures that after truncation, the resulting matrix will be full-rank and positive definite. Therefore, it guarantees that the following search direction is a decent direction

Search direction option 2. FedSONIA (Algorithm 4). FedSONIA is a modification of SONIA [22] that is adapted to the Federated Learning setting. The key idea of SONIA is to utilize curvature information in one subspace and perform a gradient step in orthogonal complement. The intuition is that, by incorporating some curvature information the resulting search direction should be â€˜betterâ€™ than a pure gradient direction, but the user has control over the dimension of each subspace, and therefore they have control over the cost of obtaining the curvature information. Truncation (Definition 1) and modified SR1 update (eq. Instead, it utilizes only Hessian-matrix product Yksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜Y_{k} and sketching matrix Sksubscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{k}.

Complexity. The per iteration complexity of FLECS depends on the chosen options for both the Hessian approximation and the iterate updates. The complexity of the Truncated L-SR1 update for one Hessian approximation consists of matrix products (Oâ€‹(mâ€‹d2))ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2(O(md^{2})) and a singular value decomposition of mÃ—mğ‘šğ‘šm\times m matrix (Oâ€‹(m3))ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š3(O(m^{3})). For the Direct update, the matrix products cost Oâ€‹(mâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2O(md^{2}) and forming the pseudo-inverse of the mÃ—mğ‘šğ‘šm\times m matrix costs Oâ€‹(m3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š3O(m^{3}). Therefore, the total complexity of either Hessian approximation update is Oâ€‹(nâ€‹mâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2O(nmd^{2}). The complexity of computing search direction via Truncated inverse Hessian approximation is Oâ€‹(d3)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘3O(d^{3}), since we utilize spectral decomposition and products of dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d matrices. FedSONIA update comprises 1) QR factorization (Oâ€‹(dâ€‹m2))ğ‘‚ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘š2(O(dm^{2})); 2) pseudoinverse of mÃ—mğ‘šğ‘šm\times m matrix (Oâ€‹(m3))ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š3(O(m^{3})); 3) spectral decomposition of mÃ—mğ‘šğ‘šm\times m matrix (Oâ€‹(m2))ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š2(O(m^{2})); which gives total complexity Oâ€‹(dâ€‹m2)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘š2O(dm^{2}). Finally, the complexity of FLECS on the server only depends on options for the search direction and equals Oâ€‹(d3+nâ€‹mâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘3ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2O(d^{3}+nmd^{2}) for Truncated Inverse Hessian approximation and Oâ€‹(nâ€‹mâ€‹d2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2O(nmd^{2}) for FedSONIA. The the worker stepâ€™s complexity consists of mğ‘šm Hessian-vector products and matrix multiplication (Oâ€‹(mâ€‹d2))ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘‘2(O(md^{2})).

4 FLECS: Convergence Theory

In this section, convergence theory for our FLECS framework is presented. We provide global convergence results in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases. A local convergence result is also presented, which shows local linear convergence of the iterates under strong convexity. We define w0subscriptğ‘¤0w_{0} to be the initial point, wâ‹†=argâ¡minwâˆˆâ„dâ¡Fâ€‹(w)superscriptğ‘¤â‹†subscriptğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¹ğ‘¤w^{\star}=\arg\min\limits_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(w) and Fâ‹†=Fâ€‹(wâ‹†)superscriptğ¹â‹†ğ¹superscriptğ‘¤â‹†F^{\star}=F(w^{\star}).

Assumption 1.

The function Fâ€‹(w)ğ¹ğ‘¤F(w) is twice continuously differentiable for all wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

We begin by listing the preliminary lemma.

Lemma 1.

Let Assumption 1 hold. Let Aksubscriptğ´ğ‘˜A_{k} be defined as in (10) depending on the choice of iterates update. Then, for any kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 there exist constants 0<Î¼1â‰¤Î¼20subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡20<\mu_{1}\leq\mu_{2} such that Î¼1â€‹Iâª¯Akâª¯Î¼2â€‹Iprecedes-or-equalssubscriptğœ‡1ğ¼subscriptğ´ğ‘˜precedes-or-equalssubscriptğœ‡2ğ¼\mu_{1}I\preceq A_{k}\preceq\mu_{2}I.

We introduce assumptions and theoretical results for the strongly convex case.

Assumption 2.

There exist positive constants Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Lğ¿L such that Î¼â€‹Iâª¯âˆ‡2Fâ€‹(w)âª¯Lâ€‹I,precedes-or-equalsğœ‡ğ¼superscriptâˆ‡2ğ¹ğ‘¤precedes-or-equalsğ¿ğ¼\mu I\preceq\nabla^{2}F(w)\preceq LI, âˆ€wâˆˆâ„dfor-allğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

The following theorem establishes global linear convergence of FLECS under strong convexity.

Theorem 1.

Let Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then for iterates {wk}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\{w_{k}\} generated by AlgorithmÂ 5 with 0<Î±k=Î±â‰¤Î¼1Î¼22â€‹L0subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ›¼subscriptğœ‡1superscriptsubscriptğœ‡22ğ¿0<\alpha_{k}=\alpha\leq\frac{\mu_{1}}{\mu_{2}^{2}L} we have Fâ€‹(wk)âˆ’Fâ‹†â‰¤(1âˆ’Î±â€‹Î¼â€‹Î¼1)kâ€‹[Fâ€‹(w0)âˆ’Fâ‹†]ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜superscriptğ¹â‹†superscript1ğ›¼ğœ‡subscriptğœ‡1ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤0superscriptğ¹â‹†F(w_{k})-F^{\star}\leq(1-\alpha\mu\mu_{1})^{k}[F(w_{0})-F^{\star}]~{} for all kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0.

We are now ready to present a convergence guarantee which shows local linear convergence for FLECS under strong convexity. Note that, while TheoremÂ 1 shows that FLECS converges linearly under strong convexity, the rate depends on parameters related to the Hessian approximations. The following local rate is independent of problem conditioning.

Theorem 2.

We introduce the assumptions for nonconvex case.

5 Numerical Experiments

We present numerical experiments for FLECS on a regularized logistic regression problem:

minâ¡{1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n1râ€‹âˆ‘j=1rlogâ¡(1+expâ¡(âˆ’biâ€‹jâ€‹aiâ€‹jTâ€‹w))+Î¼â€‹â€–wâ€–2},1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‡ğ‘¤ğœ‡superscriptnormğ‘¤2\min\left\{\tfrac{1}{n}\textstyle{\sum}_{i=1}^{n}\tfrac{1}{r}\textstyle{\sum}_{j=1}^{r}\log(1+\exp(-b_{ij}a_{ij}^{T}w))+\mu\|w\|^{2}\right\},

where {aiâ€‹j,biâ€‹j}jâˆˆ[m]subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘š\left\{a_{ij},b_{ij}\right\}_{j\in[m]} are data points on iğ‘–i-th device. We use three datasets from the LIBSVM library [7]: a9a (123123123 features), gisette-scale (500050005000 features) and real-sim (209582095820958 features). We use Top-Kğ¾K with k=4â€‹dğ‘˜4ğ‘‘k=4d and random dithering [2] applied to each matrix column with s=128ğ‘ 128s=128 levels and âˆ\infty-norm as a matrix compressors. The performance of FLECS is compared with FedNL.
In our experiments we set regularization parameter Î¼=10âˆ’5ğœ‡superscript105\mu=10^{-5}, the memory size to m=16ğ‘š16m=16 and use Bki=0superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘–0B_{k}^{i}=0 as the initial Hessian approximation for FLECS and FedNL for random dithering and Bki=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(w0)superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤0B_{k}^{i}=\nabla f_{i}(w_{0}) for Top-Kğ¾K. Truncation parameters were set to Ï‰=10âˆ’3,Î©=108formulae-sequenceğœ”superscript103Î©superscript108\omega=10^{-3},~{}\Omega=10^{8}, and for the FedSONIA update we set Ï=1Î©ğœŒ1Î©\rho=\frac{1}{\Omega} and Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1. For FLECS we use a Truncated L-SR1 Update (Algorithm 1) and a Direct update (Algorithm 2) with learning rate Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 as the Hessian learning techniques. For FedNL we use the same Î²ğ›½\beta.
The following three rules were used to compute the search direction pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}: (1) a Truncated Inverse Hessian Approximation (Algorithm 3), (2) FedSONIA (Algorithm 4) with Ïk=1Î©subscriptğœŒğ‘˜1Î©\rho_{k}=\frac{1}{\Omega}, and (3) a regularized update where Bk+1=Bk+1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€–Ckiâ€–â€‹Isubscriptğµğ‘˜1subscriptğµğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›normsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ¼B_{k+1}=B_{k}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\|C_{k}^{i}\|I, where Ckisuperscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘–C_{k}^{i} are defined in (4). The last update is motivated by [36]. Note, that in the case of FLECS this update does not guarantee positive definiteness of Hessian approximation Bksubscriptğµğ‘˜B_{k} if m<dğ‘šğ‘‘m<d, but it can still perform well if mğ‘šm is large enough.
For FedNL after random dithering the matrix Bk+1subscriptğµğ‘˜1B_{k+1} might not be symmetric, so we use 12â€‹(Bk+1+Bk+1T)12subscriptğµğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜1ğ‘‡\frac{1}{2}(B_{k+1}+B_{k+1}^{T}) as Hessian approximation. In this case, we compare algorithms on the number of bits sent to the server per iteration. For Top-K compression, the communication complexity is roughly the same, so we estimate the performance based on the number of Hessian-vector products.
For the iterates update (3) we set the step-size Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 for all algorithms and datasets except FedSONIA on gisette and real-sim, where we set Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, as it gives the best performance. Further details specifying algorithm parameters and implementation, as well as additional numerical experiments, can be found in AppendixÂ B.

6 Conclusion

This work presents a new second order framework for Federated Learning problems. The framework employs sketching and compression to ensure communication costs are low, and Hessian approximations are stored on the central server so that memory requirements for the workers is low. Due to the inclusion of partial approximate second order information, the algorithm enjoys favourable convergence guarantees, and numerical experiments show the practical benefits of our approach.

Appendix C Compressors

FLECS allows several different compression operators. In this section we give definitions and provide examples of possible compressors for our framework.

C.1 Unbiased Compressors.

Definition 2.

A random operator ğ’:â„dÃ—mâ†’â„dÃ—m:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\mathcal{C}:~{}\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} satisfying

ğ”¼ğ’¬[ğ’(X)]=X,ğ”¼ğ’[âˆ¥ğ’(X)âˆ¥F2]â‰¤(Ï‰+1)âˆ¥Xâˆ¥F2],{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{Q}}\left[\mathcal{C}(X)\right]=X,~{}~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(X)\|_{\text{F}}^{2}\right]\leq(\omega+1)\|X\|_{\text{F}}^{2}], (17)

for all Xâˆˆâ„dÃ—mğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šX\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} is a unbiased compressor operator.

Random dithering for vectors (Ï‰ğœ”\omega-quantization) [2], applied to each column of the matrix, is an example of unbiased compressors that we used in our experiments.

Definition 3.

A random operator ğ’:â„dÃ—mâ†’â„dÃ—m:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\mathcal{C}:~{}\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} satisfying

ğ”¼ğ’[ğ’(X)]â‰¤âˆ¥Xâˆ¥F,ğ”¼ğ’[âˆ¥ğ’(X)âˆ¥F2]â‰¤(1âˆ’Î´)âˆ¥Xâˆ¥F2],{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\mathcal{C}(X)\right]\leq\|X\|_{\text{F}},~{}~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(X)\|_{\text{F}}^{2}\right]\leq(1-\delta)\|X\|_{\text{F}}^{2}], (18)
